comments:
Appearance and Reality

How do we distinguish the virtual from the actual, or the factual from the fictitiousand how secure is the boundary between them? The attempt to frame a distinction between appearance and reality has always been a major preoccupation in social, political, philosophical, and literary works, leaving some to question whether ultimate reality is fated to lie beyond our grasp, others to wonder whether there is some way to access reality through appearance, and still others to question or reject the distinction entirely. This course explores the nature and challenges of the appearance/reality distinction via a diverse literature of ancient, modern, and postmodern works. While the idea that things are not always as they seem is a very old notion, it has never been more timely, as social media has greatly amplified the power to disseminate views driven by personal values, and opinions packaged as irrefutable fact. In a world permeated by allegations of fake news and allusions to virtual reality, and where once venerable grand theories can look like little more than competing and self-serving stories, sustained reflection on the validity, salience, and evolving forms of the appearance/reality distinction beckons.

If, when the lecture is full, you would like to be placed on a waitlist for this course email: arts.fyp@ubc.ca
Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: ARTS
name: ARTS 001A
title: Arts One - APPEAR + REALITY

comments:
This course will encourage an audience of students drawn from both the Faculty of Science and the Faculty of Arts, to think about global issues and the responsibilities and obligations of global citizenship in a critical manner. It will encourage them to appreciate the need for new and innovative interdisciplinary approaches (bridging the Arts and Sciences) to solve the complex problems of the 21st century.

Enrollment in the course will be restricted to 45 students with second-year standing from each of the Faculties of Arts and Science. This course will count towards an Arts requirement for Science students, and the lower-level Science requirement for Arts students.
subject: ASIC
description: Selected global issues explored through the methodologies and perspectives of both the physical and life sciences and the humanities and social sciences.
name: ASIC 200
title: Global Issues in the Arts and Sciences

description: Stellar masses and evolution. White dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Extrasolar planet formation and detection. Dark matter in the Milky Way and other galaxies. Cosmological observations and principles.

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)

name: ASTR 102
title: Introduction to Stars and Galaxies

subject: ASTR
description: A survey of recent discoveries about the planets and other objects in the solar system, without the use of advanced mathematics. The Sun, the existence of planetary systems around other stars, and the search for life. Not open to first year students and not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science.
name: ASTR 310
title: Exploring the Universe: The Solar System

subject: ASTR
description: Measurement of positions, motions, and distances in astronomy.  Temperature, masses, and spectra of stars.  Hertzsprung-Russell diagram.  Quantitative stellar structure and evolution.  Chemical composition of stars in different Galactic populations. Globular and open star clusters.
name: ASTR 205
title: Stars and Stellar Populations

subject: ASTR
description: Structure and kinematics of our galaxy. Spiral arms and dynamics of stars in spiral and elliptical galaxies. Galactic formation, evolution, dynamics, and groups. Active galaxies and quasars.
name: ASTR 300
title: Galaxies

subject: ASTR
description: Astronomical instrumentation and techniques for ground and space-based observations. Theory of measurement, imaging, interferometry and spectroscopy of electromagnetic radiation at optical, radio, infrared, and X-ray wavelengths. Astronomical data analysis.
name: ASTR 404
title: Astronomical and Astrophysical Measurements

subject: ASTR
description: Observations and basic characteristics of extrasolar planets, including their formation, evolution, and potential for supporting life.

subject: ASTR
description: Introduction to the study of the Universe as a whole. Foundations of the Hot Big Bang model, the early Universe, nucleosynthesis, the cosmic microwave background, large-scale structure, galaxy formation and quasars. Credit will be granted for only one of ASTR 403 or PHYS 571.
name: ASTR 403
title: Cosmology

subject: ASTR
description: Structure of planetary systems, planetary interiors, planet formation, planetary atmospheres, meteoritics, impact cratering.

title: Planetary Science

subject: ASTR
description: Experiments in the use of astronomical instrumentation and data analysis. Use of the 40-cm reflector, spectrograph and electronic detectors. Photometric and spectroscopic analysis of digital data.

title: Astronomical Laboratory

comments: "WICKED" Problems in Community Development: Horst W. J. Rittel and city planner, Melvin M. Webber, coined the term wicked to describe problems of governmental planning  and especially those of social or policy planning that are ill defined; and [&] rely upon elusive political judgment for resolution.  This course will engage students in a probing, practice-based dialogue exploring contemporary approaches to the taming of wicked problems in an international community development context.

comments:
Tropical Ecology & Conservation 
In this course we will explore fundamental ecological and evolutionary principles using tropical landscapes as our geographic template. We will assess the factors that make tropical systems both unique but also vulnerable to degradation, drawing from comparisons across geographic regions. While we learn about the structure, function and biological history of the tropics, we will address the myriad challenges these regions face in biodiversity loss and conservation practice. 
This course is best suited for 3rd or 4th year students with a basic background in ecology, evolution and geography. Each week, we will introduce a course theme with a lecture, to provide a sound conceptual foundation, followed by discussion based on studies in the primary literature. Students are expected to read, evaluate and discuss scientific literature relevant to these course topics.

For more information please contact Jill Jankowski at jankowsk@biodiversity.ubc.ca.

comments:
Sections 101 (Term 1) and 201 (Term 2) are the primary sections of this course (there is no meeting time for either of these sections). After registering in the primary section (101 or 201) you must also register for a lab that fits your timetable. If there is no room in the lab section that fits your schedule, register in the waitlist for that section.
Students will be moved regularly into sections as space becomes available but there are no guarantee students on wait lists will get into the course. If there is no room in any wait list that could fit your schedule contact Chin Sun: sun@zoology.ubc.ca. Be sure to include your name and student number with the lab section you are requesting.
Sections 1M1 and 1N1 are scheduled after 5pm (Vancouver time), and have been created specifically for 2020W, to provide students living outside of the North American time zones, an opportunity to participate in synchronous activities.

comments:
A graduate course on quantitative methods for data analysis in ecology and evolution. The format is a mixture of lectures and discussions on methods and inference and practical workshops using the R package. Topics include graphics, experimental design, linear models, mixed effects, likelihood, model selection, and bootstrapping.

Priority is given to Botany and Zoology students. However, interested Forestry and IRES students may contact instructor Dolph Schluter (schluter@zoology.ubc.ca) to request permission to register.

name: BMEG 320
title: Bioengineering Feedback Systems and Controls

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: BMEG
description: Fundamental principles of operation and types of medical equipment used for measurements of respiratory and circulatory systems, and biopotential signals, as well as open, minimally-invasive, and robotic surgery. Other topics include medical imaging, image processing, and simulations. Credit will only be granted for one of BMEG 321, ELEC 371.
name: BMEG 321
title: Biomedical Instrumentation

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: BMEG
description: Principles and common elements of sports-, orthopaedic-, injury- and cellular length-biomechanics. Improving sports performance and preventing overuse injuries through sports biomechanics, designing orthopaedic implants through orthopaedic biomechanics, preventing injuries through injury biomechanics and identifying and filtering cancerous blood cells through cellular biomechanics. Students who have received credit for MECH 435 cannot also receive credit for BMEG 230 or BMEG 330.
name: BMEG 330
title: Biomechanics II

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)

title: Introduction to Bioinformatics

title: Microfluidics

Students registered in the first-term offering of the course will select experiments in August; those registered in the second-term offering of the course will select experiments in December. subject: CIVL
description: The design process; graphical, visualization and computational tools; civil engineering disciplines; decision-making; teamwork; conceptual design project reflecting community, economic, environmental, sustainability and technical considerations.
name: CIVL 201
title: Introduction to Civil Engineering

subject: CIVL
description: Written and oral communication in civil engineering.  Business correspondence, business meetings, poster presentations, oral presentations and technical reports.  Restricted to students in second year of the Civil Engineering program.
name: CIVL 203
title: Technical Communication in Civil Engineering

comments: Choose one section from all 3 activity types. (e.g. Lecture, Laboratory and Tutorial)
subject: CIVL
description: Soil classification, principle of effective stress, analysis of seepage, filter criteria, introduction to shear strength and slope stability analysis.
name: CIVL 210
title: Soil Mechanics I

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these programs: BASC
in year: >=2
Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: CIVL
description: Fluid properties, hydrostatics, kinematics, and fluid dynamics: energy and momentum methods with applications. Dimensional analysis, modelling, introduction to flow in pipes and forces on immersed objects.
name: CIVL 215
title: Fluid Mechanics I

subject: CIVL
description: Theory and application of plane surveying methods. Introduction to and use of compass, transit, tape, and level. Construction and topographic surveys. Reduction of field data and construction of drawings. Demonstration of modern instruments, remote sensing methods and geographical information systems (GIS).
name: CIVL 235
title: Plane Surveying

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these programs: BASC
in year: >=2
Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: CIVL
description: Stress and strain, Hooke's law, axially loaded members, torsion, shear forces and bending moments in beams, bending and shear stresses in beams, composite members, introduction to inelastic and statically indeterminate problems.
name: CIVL 230
title: Solid Mechanics

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these programs: BASC
in year: >=2
with one of these specializations: ****CIVL
Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: CIVL
description: Deflection of beams and structural systems; analysis of determinate structures; combined axial load and bending; beam- columns; buckling (stability); biaxial stresses and strains; construction and testing of model structures.
name: CIVL 231
title: Structural Mechanics

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these programs: BASC
Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: CIVL
description: Introduction to systems engineering; applications of decision-making, modelling, and programming, including probabilistic analyses and optimization, to civil engineering projects; review of numerical methods
name: CIVL 301
title: Modelling and Decision-Making in Civil Engineering

subject: CIVL
description: Environmental engineering issues and projects; application of scientific and engineering principles to addressing these; soil, water and air pollution, and remediation.
name: CIVL 204
title: Fundamentals of Environmental Engineering

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: CIVL
description: The social and biophysical context of infrastructure and the impact of civil engineering on people, the economy, and the environment. Specific topics vary from year to year.
name: CIVL 302
title: Civil Engineering Impacts

subject: CIVL
description: Project delivery systems: traditional; construction management; turnkey; project management. Network planning methods. Activity planning, including construction methods selection. Estimating, bidding and bonding. Project control tools and procedures. Human resources, including equity considerations; occupational health and safety and quality control.
name: CIVL 300
title: Construction Engineering and Management

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: CIVL
description: Computational and numerical solutions to civil engineering problems; application to a civil engineering design project that reflects community, economic, environmental and technical considerations.
name: CIVL 303
title: Computational Tools in Civil Engineering

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in year: >1
subject: CIVL
description: Implications of a finite biosphere and the complexities inherent in environmental decision-making. Credit will only be granted for only one of CIVL 200 or CIVL 250.
name: CIVL 250
title: Engineering and Sustainable Development

subject: CIVL
description: An introduction to the planning and design of water resource systems, stream systems, and municipal and hydropower engineering.
name: CIVL 415
title: Water Resource Engineering

subject: CIVL
description: Environmental legislation; risk assessment; urban water; mass balance; water and wastewater treatment; environmental impact assessment.
name: CIVL 305
title: Introduction to Environmental Engineering

subject: CIVL
description: Application of hydraulic engineering principles to problems of environmental concern. Pollutant transport and dispersion. Mixing in rivers and lakes. Theory of jets and plumes. Design of outfall diffusers.
name: CIVL 416
title: Environmental Hydraulics

subject: CIVL
description: Hydrologic processes - weather, precipitation, infiltration, evaporation, snowmelt and runoff generation. Emphasis on quantitative techniques including: hydrograph analysis, reservoir and channel routing, statistical methods and design floods, hydrologic modelling.
name: CIVL 418
title: Engineering Hydrology

subject: CIVL
description: Linear wave theory; wave shoaling, refraction and diffraction; random waves; wave generation; long waves, tides and currents; coastal structures; beaches and coasts; mixing processes; harbour and marinas; coastal modelling. Credit will only be given for one of CIVL 417 or CIVL 540.
name: CIVL 417
title: Coastal Engineering

subject: CIVL
description: Physical and chemical properties and microstructure of hydrated Portland cement; construction practices; modern use of industrial by-products such as fly ash, blast furnace slag, silica fume and metakaolin; use of chemical admixtures; environmental issues; properties of hardened concrete; issues in standardized and accelerated testing, non-destructive testing.
name: CIVL 420
title: Concrete Technology

comments: Choose one section from all 3 activity types. (e.g. Lecture, Laboratory and Tutorial)
subject: CIVL
description: Two dimensional flow around immersed objects; velocity and pressure fields; lift and drag on cylinders and aerofoils; fluid loads on structures and structural response; pumps and turbines; analysis and design of pipeline systems; unsteady flow in pipes; frictionless waterhammer analysis.
name: CIVL 315
title: Fluid Mechanics II

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these programs: BASC
Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: CIVL
description: One-dimensional compression and stress-strain response of soils with application to estimation of the settlements and capacities of foundations and of retaining walls.
name: CIVL 311
title: Soil Mechanics II

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in year: =4
subject: CIVL
description: Structural theory and practice of ship structural design; longitudinal and transverse strength of hull girder; plates and shells; matrix analysis; introduction to classification society rules; ship section design synthesis; finite element analysis.
name: CIVL 437
title: Introduction to Ship Structures

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: CIVL
description: Introduction to limit states design of steel and timber structures: design objectives, design loads and load combinations, structural safety, material properties, design of tension and compression members, beams, columns, and connections.
name: CIVL 331
title: Steel and Timber Design

subject: CIVL
description: Building information modelling (BIM), 4D/5D modelling, design coordination, BIM execution and performance assessment, and integrated project delivery methods.  Credit will be granted for only one of CIVL 426 or CIVL 526.
name: CIVL 426
title: Virtual Design and Construction

subject: CIVL
description: Processes used in water and wastewater treatment. Conditions which necessitate treatment of water or wastewater, water and wastewater treatment processes and plant design. Municipal services required and associated with solid waste management.
name: CIVL 406
title: Water Treatment and Waste Management

subject: CIVL
description: Identification and evaluation of solutions to construction site operation problems: the relationship between design and construction; factors affecting productivity and safety; measurement of on-site performance. Credit will be granted for only one of CIVL 425 or CIVL 521.
name: CIVL 425
title: Case Studies of Construction Methods

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these programs: MASC
with one of these specializations: ****CIVL
-OR-
in one of these programs: BASC
in year: =4
with one of these specializations: ****CIVL
-OR-
in one of these programs: BASC
in year: =4
with one of these specializations: ****GEOE
subject: CIVL
description: Purpose and types of dams; design criteria; construction sequence; compaction; seepage; filter design; factors influencing the design of earth dams; stability and deformation under static and earthquake loading; slope protection; field instrumentation.
name: CIVL 413
title: Design of Earth Dams and Containment Structures

subject: CIVL
description: An introduction to the process of foundation engineering. Empirical and analytical approaches used in current professional practice. Topics include site investigation, preloading, liquefaction assessment, ground improvement, design of shallow and deep foundations, and retaining structures. The importance of geology and technical communication are emphasized.
name: CIVL 410
title: Foundation Engineering I

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in year: =4
with one of these specializations: ****IGEN
-OR-
in year: >=3
with one of these specializations: ****GEOE
-OR-
in year: =4
with one of these specializations: ****ENVE
subject: CIVL
description: Time value of money; cash flow analysis; comparing options; depreciation, taxes, and inflation; financial accounting; company structures; public sector projects; decision-making.
name: CIVL 403
title: Engineering Economic Analysis

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these programs: BASC
subject: CIVL
description: The analysis and design of the elements of transportation facilities in development of transport technology; vehicle motion; vehicle/pavement interaction; elements of road design; principles of queuing and roadway capacity; rail transit performance and capacity analysis; economics as applied to transport.
name: CIVL 340
title: Transportation Engineering I

subject: CIVL
description: The structure and properties of common Civil Engineering materials: aggregates, Portland cement, concrete, wood, steel and other construction materials. The emphasis is on the relationship between the structure of materials and their mechanical and durability properties.
name: CIVL 320
title: Civil Engineering Materials

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in year: =4
subject: CIVL
description: The Engineers and Geoscientists Act; professional ethics, conflicts of interest, confidentiality and accountability; health and safety; sustainable development and environmental stewardship; equity considerations; design and construction contracts, specifications and tendering; labour and employment law; dispute resolution; evidence and expert witnesses; torts and legal liability.
name: CIVL 402
title: Professionalism and Law in Civil Engineering

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these programs: BASC
subject: CIVL
description: Design of municipal infrastructure, including streets, water supply networks, and sewers, garbage collection and solid waste management. Focus is on solutions for providing an adequate water supply, collecting and disposing of stormwater and sewage, and managing excess stormwater flow.
name: CIVL 409
title: Municipal Engineering

comments: Choose one section from all 3 activity types. (e.g. Lecture, Laboratory and Tutorial)
subject: CIVL
description: Non-linear response of reinforced concrete members subjected to axial load, bending and shear; design of simple one-way members including beams, columns, slabs and footings.
name: CIVL 430
title: Design of Concrete Structures

subject: CIVL
description: Design of steel structures to resist vertical and lateral loads. Floor and roof systems including conceptual layout, floor deck, beams, joists, trusses, and columns. Stability issues and limit states design. Connections and construction aspects. Seismic design.
name: CIVL 432
title: Advanced Structural Steel Design

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: CIVL
description: Introduction to indeterminate structural analysis; approximate analysis of structures; calculation of displacements using virtual work; flexibility (force) method; stiffness method for frames; moment distribution method; influence lines, introduction to structural dynamics.
name: CIVL 332
title: Structural Analysis

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Planning of civil engineering projects using networking techniques and time space methods. Treatment of resources and cash flow. Activity planning. Concepts of control at the project and activity levels.
name: CIVL 520
title: Construction Planning and Control

subject: CIVL
description: Design of continuous reinforced concrete building frames and structures.
name: CIVL 433
title: Advanced Concrete Design

subject: CIVL
description: Environmental contamination, regulatory requirements, site investigation, migration of contaminants, containment systems, site remediation technologies, design considerations related to soil-contaminant interactions, hydrogeology, geochemistry and types of contaminants. Design and performance case histories.
name: CIVL 408
title: Geo-Environmental Engineering

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in year: =4
subject: CIVL
description: Transportation systems planning and analysis: data needs; surveys and analysis; sampling techniques; trip generation; trip distribution; modal choice; trip assignment; traffic impact studies; system evaluation. Credit will be granted for only one of CIVL 441, CIVL 583 or PLAN 535.
name: CIVL 441
title: Transportation Planning and Analysis

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Structural behaviour of steel; plastic analysis of cross-sections and steel structures; seismic design of steel buildings.
name: CIVL 511
title: Advanced Topics in Steel Structures

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Causes of earthquakes. Fault mechanisms. Wave motions. Magnitudes and intensities. Regional seismicity and risk analysis. Attenuation of ground motion parameters with distance. Development of site specific ground motions. Selection of earthquake records and construction of design spectra.
name: CIVL 504
title: Seismicity and Seismic Design Parameters

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: CIVL
description: Integration and application of previously acquired knowledge and skills to find design solutions for a multi-disciplinary civil engineering design project.  Focus on detailed design.
name: CIVL 446
title: Civil Engineering Design Project II.

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Response of structures to earthquakes; concept of ductility; development of seismic design codes. Hierarchy of analytical tools; quasi-static, modal, and nonlinear analyses. Modelling of structures. Soil-structure interaction.
name: CIVL 505
title: Seismic Response of Structures

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Application of seismic design principles to the design of building structures with particular emphasis on performance-based seismic design.
name: CIVL 506
title: Seismic Design of Structures

subject: CIVL
description: Seminar or lecture. Registration will take place on the first day of class by the Instructor.
name: CIVL 498J
title: Topics in Civil Engineering - BRIDGE ENGINRING

subject: CIVL
description: Seminar or lecture. Registration will take place on the first day of class by the Instructor.
name: CIVL 498M
title: Topics in Civil Engineering - DSGN MSNRY STRUC

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Fundamental analysis of simple structures subjected to dynamic loadings; vibration problems in structures; linear and nonlinear structural response of simple systems; numerical methods for practical vibration analysis.
name: CIVL 507
title: Dynamics of Structures I

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Case studies in construction methods and solutions to construction site operation problems. Construction productivity, performance measurement, safety, quality, and other production issues. Credit will be granted for only one of CIVL 425 or CIVL 521.
name: CIVL 521
title: Construction Methods and Performance

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in year: =4
Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: CIVL
description: Integration and application of previously acquired knowledge and skills to find design solutions for a multi-disciplinary civil engineering project.  Focus on conceptual and preliminary design..
name: CIVL 445
title: Civil Engineering Design Project I.

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Behaviour of timber structural elements using limit states design principles; joints and fasteners, sawn lumber and engineered wood products, light frame systems and shear walls. Credit will be granted for only one of CIVL 439 or CIVL 516.
name: CIVL 516
title: Behaviour of Timber Structures

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: CIVL
description: Traffic operations and network analysis: traffic studies and data design; traffic stream flow and roadway analysis; weaving and interchange ramp analysis; intersection traffic control measures and control design; progressive signal system design; flows prediction; road network simulation and assignment algorithms; motor vehicle accident analysis; field exercises.
name: CIVL 440
title: Transportation Engineering II

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Dynamic response of discrete and continuous systems; structural property matrices and eigenvalue problem; introduction to random vibrations; wave propagation analysis; experimental techniques and computer modelling.
name: CIVL 508
title: Dynamics of Structures II

comments: Choose one section from all 3 activity types. (e.g. Lecture, Laboratory and Tutorial)
subject: CIVL
description: Introduction to open channel hydraulics, engineering hydrology, and water resource systems; estimation of design discharge; flood statistics; nonuniform steady open channel flow; energy and momentum principles, backwater analysis; culvert and bridge hydraulics.
name: CIVL 316
title: Hydrology and Open Channel Flow

subject: CIVL
description: Design of timber structural elements using limit states design principles; joints and fasteners, sawn lumber and engineered wood products, light frame systems and shear walls. Credit will be granted for only one of CIVL 439 or CIVL 516.
name: CIVL 439
title: Design of Timber Structures

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Mechanics of structural concrete; comparison of analytical predictions and experimental results; simplified procedure; design using strut-and-tie models; seismic design of concrete buildings
name: CIVL 513
title: Concrete Structures

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Nonlinear behaviour of structures and the formulation of elements to model such behaviour; solution strategies; nonlinear material and section response; nonlinear dynamic analysis; nonlinear geometry; application of nonlinear analysis in engineering practice.
name: CIVL 509
title: Nonlinear Structural Analysis

subject: CIVL
description: Shear flow, shear deformation, St. Venant torsion, warping torsion, P-delta and geometric stiffness, buckling of columns and frames, cylindrical shells, beams on elastic foundation, shear wall analysis, elasto-plastic analysis. Introduction to the finite element method.
name: CIVL 435
title: Advanced Structural Analysis

subject: CIVL
description: Aspects of Geotechnical Engineering. Design considerations illustrated by case histories pertinent to BC. Topics include: site investigation, terrain analyses, in situ testing, groundwater problems, deep foundations, tie back walls and bracing, tailings impoundments, Northern construction, ground ice, dikes and dams engineering. Many case histories presented in part by prominent consulting engineers in BC.
name: CIVL 411
title: Foundation Engineering II

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Perspectives of project management as it relates to civil engineering. Case studies are used to illustrate key issues.
name: CIVL 523
title: Project Management for Engineers

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Probability theory and random variables. Performance functions and probability of non-performance: simulations and FORM/SORM methods. Applications. System reliability. Time-dependent reliability and introduction to stochastic processes.
name: CIVL 518
title: Reliability and Structural Safety

subject: CIVL
description: Building science concepts associated with the design of modern buildings, focusing particularly on the building envelope's role in environmental separation, controlling the movement of heat, air, and water in liquid and vapour states.
name: CIVL 478
title: Building Science

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL

name: CIVL 524
title: Legal Aspects of Project and Construction Management

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL

Topics treated: modelling of capital expenditures, revenues and operating expenditures, project financing, sensitivity analysis, risk analysis and management.
name: CIVL 522
title: Project and Construction Economics

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Building information modelling (BIM), 4D/5D modelling, design coordination, BIM execution and performance assessment, and integrated project delivery methods. Credit will be granted for only one of CIVL 426 or CIVL 526.
name: CIVL 526
title: Virtual Design and Construction

subject: CIVL
description: Further techniques in matrix structural analysis; non-rigid supports, temperature-shrinkage effects, computer implementation; matrix representation of structural dynamics; mode shapes, natural frequencies, continuous systems; lumped mass models, modal analysis, response spectra.
name: CIVL 436
title: Matrix Structural Analysis and Dynamics

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL
description: Non-destructive testing, repair, rehabilitation, strengthening, high performance plain and fiber reinforced concrete, shotcrete, fibre reinforced polymer laminates, analysis, case studies.
name: CIVL 529
title: Condition Assessment and Rehabilitation of Civil Infrastructure

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: CIVL

name: CIVL 561
title: Risk and Remediation in Geo-environment

subject: CPSC

name: CPSC 110
title: Computation, Programs, and Programming

subject: CPSC
description: Process synchronization and communication schemes, including message-passing and concepts of monitor and serializer. Virtual memory systems management and the problem of information sharing in such systems. The working set principle. Traps and interrupt handling. Elementary queuing theory and its application such as process scheduling, system balancing and load control. File systems and operating system design methodologies.
name: CPSC 415
title: Advanced Operating Systems

subject: CPSC
description: Algorithms, architectures, and programming paradigms for parallel computation.  Shared memory, message passing, and data parallel architectures and programming models.  Parallel algorithms including reduce, scan, and sorting networks.  Reasoning about the correctness of parallel programs.  Performance analysis and measurement for parallel programs.
name: CPSC 418
title: Parallel Computation

comments: The Interactive Digital Media Practicum Course is by application only. To apply: (1) Register for the waitlist section for the offering you want to join. (2) Apply for the course (and learn more about it) at https://thecdm.ca/program/ubc-sfu-digital-media-practicum. Applications are due at 11:59PM (Vancouver time) on October 25 for Jan-Apr offerings and March 11 for May-Aug offerings. (When the deadline is a weekend/holiday, applications are due at 11:59PM on the next business day.) If you are unable to register for the waitlist because of credit limit issues--e.g., arranging backup courses in case you are not accepted to the practicum--please apply at the website listed above and document your reasons for being unable to register for the waitlist.
subject: CPSC
description: Design and implementation of interactive digital media systems using modern processes and tools. Projects provided by external clients or vetted entrepreneurial pitches are developed by interdisciplinary teams composed of one CPSC 491 student and multiple Master of Digital Media students.
name: CPSC 491
title: Interactive Digital Media Practicum

subject: DES
description: Essential processes and methods for thinking in three-dimensional spatial terms.

name: DES 231
title: Site Analysis and Planning

subject: DES
description: Techniques in architectural drawing, two-dimensional representation, three-dimensional representation and general visual literacy. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 320, ARCH 515 or DES 211.
name: DES 211
title: Design Media I

subject: DES
description: Techniques applicable to analytic and technical drawing used in architecture, landscape architecture, and urban design with focus primarily on analog drawing techniques. Open to all UBC students regardless of prior experience. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 110 or DES 110.
name: DES 110
title: Measured Architectural Drawing

subject: DES
description: A global history of architecture pre-20th century. Credit will be granted for only one of  DES 321, ARCH 404 or ARCH 505.

title: Architectural History I

description: Advanced techniques in architectural representation and discourse in digital representation and digital making. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCH 437, ARCH 517 or DES 212.
name: DES 212
title: Design Media II

name: DES 232
title: Material Culture

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: DES

title: Sustainability by Design

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)

name: DES 200
title: Design Thinking

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: DES
description: The unfolding architecture and urbanism of Metro Vancouver. Using Vancouver as a laboratory to examine the historical transformation of the built environment, and how this has affected particular activities, land uses, and social groups within the region. This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 220 or DES 220.
name: DES 220
title: Architecture in Context: Vancouver and its Region

subject: ECON
description: A study of the Canadian labour market. Labour supply, the allocation of the time among work and non-market activity, participation in the labour force, education and training. The demand for labour. The determination of wages and employment. The effect of unions on wages and employment. The wage structure, wage differentials by occupation, industry, race and sex. Unemployment. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 360 and 460.
name: ECON 360
title: Labour Economics

subject: ECON
description: Current topics in industrial organization and regulation with emphasis on Canadian federal and provincial policy. The content will differ from year to year. Possible subjects include the regulation of transportation and communications, environmental regulation, marketing boards and other forms of agricultural regulation, competition and anti-combines policy, industrial organization and trade policy, and issues in consumer protection.
name: ECON 365
title: Topics in Canadian Industrial Organization and Regulation Policy

subject: ECON
description: The role of government in the economy; efficiency and economic justice. Theory of public goods; applications to topics such as education, medical care and social services. Pricing and investment rules for public enterprises.
name: ECON 451
title: Economics of Public Expenditures

subject: ECON
description: Examination of two or three selected policy problems from areas of taxation, income security, and public expenditures. Topics to be selected each year from areas of current or recent policy debate. Examples include public pension policy, privatization and public services, income tax or sales tax reform, federal-provincial cost sharing programs, tax incentives versus direct expenditures, welfare reform.
name: ECON 350
title: Public Finance Policy Topics

subject: ECON
description: Principles of rational behaviour in strategic situations and various notions of equilibrium useful in predicting outcomes. Applications from economics, business, politics, law and biology.
name: ECON 421
title: Introduction to Game Theory and Applications.

subject: ECON
description: Divergence in the world economy, poverty, consequences of initial inequality, institutions, the impact of history, recent developmental experience--some case studies, labour and credit markets, the trickle down process.
name: ECON 442
title: Issues in Economic Development

subject: ECON
description: Application of economic analysis to the management of renewable resources. Special attention is given to criteria for the optimal use of depleting resources such as forests and water. Other topics include public policy with regard to environmental quality, conservation, and outdoor recreation.
name: ECON 472
title: Economics of Renewable Resources

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: ECON
description: Theory and practice of the analytical application of economics. Causality, empirical analysis, and the application of theoretical models through engagement in applied work.
name: ECON 398
title: Introduction to Applied Economics

subject: ECON
description: The determinants of trade patterns, trade policy, tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade, political economy of protectionism, bilateral and multilateral trade disputes, trade liberalization, trade and development. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 355 and 455.
name: ECON 355
title: Introduction to International Trade

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)

subject: ENPH
description: An optional course for those students wishing to continue their project work beyond the development in ENPH 479.
name: ENPH 480
title: Engineering Physics Project IV

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: ENPH
description: Engineering project planning, execution and reporting. The course involves carrying out an open-ended Engineering project to meet specific performance metrics on an industry relevant topic selected by instructors. Reporting on progress is both oral and written.
name: ENPH 353
title: Engineering Physics Project I

subject: ENPH
description: Some of the experiments will be based on the lecture material for PHYS 301. Other techniques and subjects will also be covered.
name: ENPH 352
title: Laboratory Techniques in Physics

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: ENPH
description: Projects designed to give students research development and design experience. Projects are provided by research faculty in Science and Engineering and from local industry.
name: ENPH 479
title: Engineering Physics Project III

subject: ENPH
description: Project planning, management and reporting. This course involves writing a project proposal, carrying out an open-ended Engineering project, and reporting the results both orally and in writing.
name: ENPH 459
title: Engineering Physics Project II

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: ENVE
description: Analysis of integrated environmental systems, quantification of fundamental chemical and biological processes, systems design, evaluation of environmental impact, future trends.
name: ENVE 202
title: Environmental Engineering Science

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: ENVE
description: Sustainability vocabulary and systems theory relevant to environmental engineering practice,  foundational sustainability topics including those relating to urban ecology, industrial ecology/circular economy, and humanitarian engineering, stakeholder analysis, communication,  and adaptive change leadership skills
name: ENVE 203
title: Environmental Engineering and Sustainability

subject: ENVE
description: All aspects of technical communication, including report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation, applied to environmental engineering specific cases and projects.
name: ENVE 201
title: Technical Communications for Environmental Engineering

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in year: >=3
subject: ENVR
description: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student.  Permission of an ENSC advisor and of the supervising faculty member is required prior to registration.
name: ENVR 448A
title: Directed Studies in Environmental Science - DIR STD ENVR SCI

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: ENVE
description: Environmental Engineering design and decision-making, analysis tools and techniques, data illustration and other communication techniques, professional development including ethics and equity. Subject themes include water, air and soil.
name: ENVE 200
title: Environmental Engineering Design and Decision Making

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in year: >=3
subject: ENVR
description: Sustainability analysis through a series of case studies. Example approaches include cost-benefit analysis, trade-offs analysis, and life-cycle analysis. Active learning in a computer lab using real-world data.
name: ENVR 440
title: Analytical Methods in Sustainability Science

subject: ENVR
description: Seminars and field trips introducing the major global, regional, and local environmental issues facing human societies.
name: ENVR 200
title: Introduction to Environmental Science

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these programs: BSC
in year: =4
with one of these specializations: ****ENSC
subject: ENVR
name: ENVR 449
title: Environmental Science HonoursThesis

subject: ENVR
description: Current issues. Application to agricultural, energy, and resource systems in terrestrial and aquatic contexts. Analysis of complex problems; incorporation of science into novel interdisciplinary solutions.
name: ENVR 430
title: Ecological Dimensions of Sustainability

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in year: >=3
subject: ENVR

title: Directed Studies in Environmental Science - DIR STD ENVR SCI

subject: ENVR
description: Instructor-guided collaboration between student teams and community partners on community-based environmental science projects. Teams articulate project questions and goals, devise methods, conduct research and communicate results. Credit will be given for only one of ENVR 400 or ENVR 449.
name: ENVR 400
title: Community Project in Environmental Science

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: APSC,SCIE
in year: >=4
subject: ENVR
description: The role of energy in human societies throughout history and the environmental and social implications of energy use.  Coverage of both the science and policy of energy use.  Energy supply and demand, energy transitions, analytical tools, impacts, and alternatives.
name: ENVR 410
title: Energy, Environment, and Society

subject: ENVR
description: Environmental research.  Students investigate research methodologies and reporting in a range of scientific disciplines and fields.
name: ENVR 300
title: Introduction to Research in Environmental Science

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: EOSC
description: Introduction to the techniques of geological mapping and the interpretation of field data. Includes three one-day field trips on weekends plus a seven-day field school after Spring examinations. A fee is to be paid by January 31.
name: EOSC 223
title: Field Techniques

subject: EOSC
description: Introduction to processes in ocean and atmosphere. Heat, current, winds, clouds, marine life, resources. Effects of coupling, climate change, pollution. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list, within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.)
name: EOSC 112
title: The Fluid Earth: Atmosphere and Ocean

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: EOSC
description: Measuring geological time and understanding Earth history using stratigraphic principles, paleontology and radioactive decay. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
name: EOSC 222
title: Geological Time and Stratigraphy

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: EOSC
description: Theory and practice of site investigation for geological engineers, including background studies, field work, remote sensing, development of ground models, importance of geological variability and uncertainty. Impacts on design, project risk and decision making.
name: EOSC 240
title: Site Investigation

subject: EOSC
description: Introduction to causes and physical characteristics of disasters such as volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, tsunamis, hurricanes, storm surge, thunderstorms, tornadoes, landslides, wind waves, meteor impacts, mass extinctions.
name: EOSC 114
title: The Catastrophic Earth: Natural Disasters

subject: EOSC
description: Cutting edge problems in earth, ocean, atmospheric and planetary sciences.  Topics will be introduced through discussions of the current literature.
name: EOSC 212
title: Topics in the Earth and Planetary Sciences.

subject: EOSC
description: Combining basic physical principles with their mathematical description and generating computational models that describe them. Introduction to basic building blocks in modelling, simulation and parameter estimation.
name: EOSC 213
title: Computational Methods in Geological Engineering

subject: EOSC
description: Earth's tectonics, climate, and oceans during the time of the dinosaurs.  Reading the fossil record of Earth from its earliest origins up to and including the Mesozoic, 250 - 65 million years ago.
name: EOSC 116
title: Mesozoic Earth: Time of the Dinosaurs.

subject: EOSC
description: Introduction to diversity of marine habitats and ecosystems; hydrothermal vent, intertidal, coral reef, estuarine, deep sea, and polar ecosystems; impacts of ecosystem change; evolution of ocean plankton; invasive species; climate change; pollution.
name: EOSC 270
title: Marine Ecosystems

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: EOSC
description: Mathematical computer-based problem solving in the physical, chemical, and biological sciences. Problems drawn from studies of the earth, the oceans and the atmosphere. Credit will be granted for only one of APSC 160, CPSC 301, or EOSC 211.
name: EOSC 211
title: Computer Methods in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: EOSC
description: Introduction to crystallography, physical and chemical properties of minerals. Recognition and identification of common minerals. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
name: EOSC 220
title: Introductory Mineralogy

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: EOSC
description: Focus on the interaction between society and the geologic environment.  Locating, assessing and developing natural resources; understanding and preparing for natural hazards, design of structures and waste disposal sites.  For applied science and forestry students only.
name: EOSC 210
title: Earth Science for Engineers

subject: EOSC
description: Application of classical theory of scalar and vector fields to geophysical sciences. Conductive, convective and radiative energy flux, gravitation, electrostatics, and magnetostatics. Gauss' and Stokes' theorems.
name: EOSC 250
title: Fields and Fluxes

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: EOSC
description: Optical mineralogy and the classification and genesis of igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks.
name: EOSC 221
title: Introductory Petrology

comments:
This course is restricted to students
not in any of these faculties: APSC,SCIE
in year: >1
subject: EOSC
description: The Earth as a planet: its composition, internal dynamics, and surface evolution. Rotation, magnetic field, plate tectonics, earthquakes, volcanoes. The ocean, atmosphere, and biosphere as components of a varying geo-environment. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. No background in science or mathematics is required. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
name: EOSC 310
title: The Earth and the Solar System

subject: EOSC
description: Origin, properties, valuation, prospecting and geology of gold, platinum, silver, diamonds, rubies, emeralds, and other precious metals and gems.
name: EOSC 118
title: Earth's Treasures: Gold and Gems

subject: EOSC
description: Earth's origin, composition, structure, and natural resources. Plate tectonics as the driving force for volcanism, mountain building, and earthquakes.  Imaging Earth's interior. Environmental geoscience and sustainability. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list for the Faculty of Science section of  the Calendar.)
name: EOSC 110
title: The Solid Earth: A Dynamic Planet

comments:
This course is restricted to students
not in any of these faculties: APSC,SCIE
in year: >1
subject: EOSC
description: An introduction to the oceans and the processes that have shaped them, their composition and movement, waves, tides, beaches, interactions with the atmosphere and human exploitation of the non-living resources. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science or Applied Science. No background in Science or Mathematics is required.
name: EOSC 314
title: The Ocean Environment

subject: EOSC
description: An examination of the processes that shape and change the planet earth. This laboratory course is an appropriate complement to EOSC 110, EOSC 112, EOSC 114, EOSC 116 but can also be taken independently.
name: EOSC 111
title: Laboratory Exploration of Planet Earth

comments:
This course is restricted to students
not in any of these faculties: APSC,SCIE
in year: >1
subject: EOSC
description: An introduction to life in the oceans, its variety and evolution; primary producers and their links to the environment, zooplankton, marine communities, living marine resources and their role in today's world. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science or Applied Science.
name: EOSC 315
title: The Ocean Ecosystem

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: EOSC
description: Origin, diagenesis and geochemistry of sediments and sedimentary rocks.
name: EOSC 320
title: Sedimentology

subject: EOSC
description: An overview of the geology and tectonic evolution of North America; comparisons and contrasts between Precambrian rocks of the North American craton and Phanerozoic belts of the Cordilleran, Appalachian, Ouachita and Innuitian orogens;  interrelations between sedimentation, deformation, metamorphism and magmatism in a plate tectonic context.
name: EOSC 332
title: Tectonic Evolution of North America

subject: EOSC
description: Mechanisms and processes of past and future global environmental and climate change.
name: EOSC 340
title: Global Climate Change

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: EOSC
description: Analytical methods in geochemistry, major and trace element geochemistry, radiogenic isotopes, geochemistry of seawater, the mantle, basalts, subduction zones, sedimentary rocks, continental crust.
name: EOSC 333
title: Elemental and Isotopic Geochemistry

subject: EOSC
description: Recording and processing geological data in the field. Held within the three weeks following April examinations after third year. A special fee is to be paid by January 31.
name: EOSC 328
title: Field Geology

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: EOSC
description: Application of rock mechanics, hydrogeology, and engineering design tools in realistically complex geological environments. Influence and treatment of geological uncertainty, and use of field data, geotechnical monitoring, and numerical analyses for tunnelling, mining and rock slope engineering projects. Case histories.
name: EOSC 433
title: Geological Engineering Practice I - Rock Engineering

subject: EOSC
description: Application of data analysis and empirical modelling strategies for conducting a data-oriented research in geosciences; from setting research questions and hypothesis to delivering and interpreting results. Examples are drawn from across the Earth, ocean, atmospheric and planetary sciences.
name: EOSC 410
title: Geoscientific Data Analysis and Empirical Modelling

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: EOSC
description: Hooke's law for isotropic continua, elastic wave equation, reflection and refraction methods for imaging the Earth's internal structure, plane waves in an infinite medium and interaction with boundaries, body wave seismology, inversion of travel-time curves, generalized ray theory, crustal seismology, surface waves and earthquake source studies.
name: EOSC 353
title: Seismology

subject: EOSC

title: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES

subject: EOSC

A practical course on computer techniques applied to the analysis of a wide range of geophysical phenomena.
name: EOSC 354
title: Analysis of Time Series and Inverse Theory for Earth Scientists

Paleontological evidence for early life; the colonization of oceanic and terrestrial environments and; the evolution of the primates.

title: Paleontology

subject: FNEL
description: Foundational concepts in the critical study of cultural, historical, social, and political factors that impact language loss, retention, and revival. Introducing strategies and practical methodologies for collaborative, interdisciplinary, community-based documentation and revitalization projects for First Nations and Indigenous languages.
name: FNEL 180
title: Introduction to Endangered Language Documentation and Revitalization

subject: FNEL
description: Examines the complementary and intersecting roles of libraries, archives, and museums in collections acquisition, development, curation, preservation, and access traditions pertaining to First Nations languages, to explore how each can contribute to endangered language and cultural heritage sustainability.
name: FNEL 481
title: Heritage Resources in Endangered First Nations Language Revitalization

subject: FNEL
description: Foundational concepts in the discipline of compiling, editing, managing and hosting dictionaries, also known as lexicography. Special focus on the technical and ethical considerations for community-based lexicography projects for endangered and BC First Nations languages.
name: FNEL 382
title: Lexicography for Endangered Languages

subject: FNEL
description: Critical exploration of the links between linguistic, biological and cultural diversity; including connections with linguistic relativity, linguistic identity, language and place; and strategies for collective, interdisciplinary action to promote and support the protection of languages, cultures, and the environment.
name: FNEL 381
title: Biocultural Diversity: Language, Community, and Environment

subject: FNEL
description: Development of skills in the documentation, transcription and analysis of grammatical structures in endangered languages, focusing on the diversity within BC Aboriginal languages. description: Introduces network concepts and methods for exploring social and organizational connectivity for work, socializing, and knowledge production. Examines impact of social media on connections that span space and place; peer production on authority structures; ubiquitous mobile connectivity on daily life.
name: INFO 250
title: Networks, Crowds, and Communities

subject: ITAL
description: Introduction to the essentials of Italian vocabulary, expressions, grammar and cultural life. Focus on listening, reading, speaking and writing skills in everyday situations in the present tense. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives.
name: ITAL 101
title: Beginners' Italian I

subject: ITAL
description: Introduction to complex language structures used to communicate in a variety of situations by using different tenses and modes. Enhanced ability to comprehend, interact and express wishes or feelings in common personal and social contexts. Aligned with CEFR level A2 objectives.
name: ITAL 201
title: Elementary Italian I

subject: ITAL
description: Expansion of fundamental notions and presentation of elaborate structures, present, past and future tenses and different modes. Enriched opportunities to explore Italian culture and develop intercultural skills. Aligned with CEFR level A2 objectives.
name: ITAL 202
title: Elementary Italian II

subject: ITAL
description: Continuation of foundational elements of Italian language. Development of listening, reading, speaking and writing skills in the context of everyday situations in the present and past tenses. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives.
name: ITAL 102
title: Beginners' Italian II

subject: ITAL
description: Advanced grammar structures in context, lexical repertoire and cultural elements to further increase learners ability to communicate in most situations, including complex conversations. Aligned with CEFR level B1 objectives.
name: ITAL 301
title: Intermediate Italian I

subject: ITAL
description: Expansion of and reflection on the use of complex grammatical structures in context to broaden lexical repertoire. Enhances proficiency through written communication and discussion of relevant cultural topics. Aligned with CEFR level B1 objectives.
name: ITAL 302
title: Intermediate Italian II

subject: ITAL
description: The development of modern and contemporary Italian literature and culture against the background of social and historical events. Alternates with ITAL 303.
name: ITAL 304
title: Italian Literature and Culture of the Modern and Contemporary Age

subject: ITAL
description: Continues building fluency, accuracy and proficiency at an autonomous level in spoken and written communication. Emphasis on culturally contextualized grammar structures and vocabulary, critical reading and discussion of a variety of texts. Aligned with CEFR level B2 objectives.
name: ITAL 401
title: Upper-Intermediate Italian I

subject: ITAL
description: Italian literature of the Middle Ages in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Dante and his contemporaries and/or immediate followers (may include Petrarch and Boccaccio). Precludes credit for ITST 414.
name: ITAL 404
title: Italian Literature of the Middle Ages

subject: ITST
description: Italian literature of the 20th century in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Precludes credit for ITAL 409.
name: ITST 419
title: Topics in Modern and Contemporary Italian Literature and Culture in Translation

subject: ITST
description: The cultural, literary, philosophical roots of Fascism and its evolution: its policies in literature, sports, cinema, architecture, racial legislation, and colonial adventures.
name: ITST 345
title: Italian Fascism in Interdisciplinary Perspective

subject: ITST
description: A study of the genre of the novella as an expression of social and political contexts within and across cultures from its inception in feudal times to the post-modern age.
name: ITST 333
title: Masterpieces of the Novella in Italian Literature

subject: ITST
description: A survey of the major classics of post-WWII Italian Neorealism in cinema emphasizing their historical, political, social, philosophical and technical contexts.
name: ITST 385
title: Italian Cinema: Neorealism

subject: ITST
description: Italian literature of the Middle Ages in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Dante and his contemporaries and/or immediate followers (may include Petrarch and Boccaccio). Precludes credit for ITAL 404.
name: ITST 414
title: Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Middle Ages in Translation

subject: ITST
description: Key moments and texts about intercultural exchange between Italy and China since the beginning of the twentieth century in their social, historical, and political contexts.
name: ITST 377
title: Cultural Exchange between Modern Italy and China

subject: ITST
description: Where do Italy's glamour, lifestyle, traditions come from? This course introduces Italy's multifaceted ways of being and the cultural creations of the peninsula in their context.
name: ITST 110
title: "Made in Italy"

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: IWME
description: Chemical and microbiological quality and contaminations, techniques and analytical procedures for assessing and monitoring chemical and microbiological water quality; water and wastewater quality standards, pollution prevention strategies and policies; risk analysis; asset management.
name: IWME 504
title: Water and Wastewater Management Strategies

subject: ITST
description: The debate around nation vs. empire vs. republic, from the Napoleonic age to our days, as captured in Italy's microcosm, condensing and often anticipating issues that have later become global.
name: ITST 232
title: Introduction to Italian Culture II: From the Modern to the Post-Colonial Age

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: IWME
description: Art and science of modelling for integrated water resources planning and management; practice of developing and deploying simulation and optimization models to solve water problems; risk informed decision making frameworks and stakeholder processes for analysis of water resources systems.
name: IWME 505
title: Water Resources Systems Planning and Management

subject: JAPN
description: Integrated coverage of topics on culture and  cross-cultural communication designed to develop competencies in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Offered in Term 1. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 360 and JAPN 361 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 360 or JAPN 212 or both JAPN 210, JAPN 211 or both JAPN 320, JAPN 321.
name: JAPN 360
title: Intensive Intermediate Japanese I

comments: NOTE: If this is the first time you take a Japanese course at UBC, CONSULT THE REGISTRATION GUIDELINES for Japanese on the departmental website at www.asia.ubc.ca to find out which course is appropriate for your level before registration. Those who have prior knowledge in Japanese (except those who have studied at a BC high school or BC college) and those whose parent speaks Japanese must take a placement exam/interview before registering for a course. Schedules for the placement exams are also posted on our departmental website as you can go to http://asia.ubc.ca/undergraduate/placement-tests/ for further information. In order for students to advance from one level of classes in one language to the next level in that same language, they must earn at least an average of 60% in the classes in that language at the level immediately below the level into which they wish to advance. This would apply to all the students in our language classes, not just the language majors.

comments: NOTE: If this is the first time you take a Japanese course at UBC, CONSULT THE REGISTRATION GUIDELINES for Japanese on the departmental website at www.asia.ubc.ca to find out which course is appropriate for your level before registration. Those who have prior knowledge in Japanese (except those who have studied at a BC high school or BC college) and those whose parent speaks Japanese must take a placement exam/interview before registering for a course. Schedules for the placement exams are also posted on our departmental website as you can go to http://asia.ubc.ca/undergraduate/placement-tests/ for further information. In order for students to advance from one level of classes in one language to the next level in that same language, they must earn at least an average of 60% in the classes in that language at the level immediately below the level into which they wish to advance. This would apply to all the students in our language classes, not just the language majors.

This is an elective course that does not fulfill writing requirements in any faculty or the literature requirement in the Faculty of Arts.
name: LING 140
title: Challenging Language Myths

subject: LING
description: A survey of the linguistic map of the world, examining how languages are genetically classified and how different languages evolve. Principles underlying different writing systems and the decipherment of historical documents. Issues of languages in contact, minority language endangerment, language death and the role of English as a world language. Recommended but not required for an honours, major, or minor in linquistics or speech sciences.
name: LING 101
title: Languages of the World

comments: This class meets four hours per week. Sign up for the lecture and one discussion section.
Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: LING
description: Introduction to phonetics and phonology; training in the identification and production of speech sounds; principles and methods for describing and writing the sound system of a language; phonological theory with reference to selected languages; the interface between phonology and morphology. Analytical practice and seminar discussion.
name: LING 200
title: Linguistic Theory and Analysis I

subject: LING
description: Skills and strategies for second language acquisition, through the foundations of pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar, and pragmatics, connected to the practical, social, and personal challenges of language learning.
name: LING 170
title: Introduction to How to Learn a Language

subject: LING
description: Introduction to speech and hearing sciences, with emphasis on the clinical perspectives of audiology and speech pathology.
name: LING 209
title: Clinical Topics in Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences

comments: This class meets four hours per week. Sign up for the lecture and one discussion section.
Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: LING
description: Introduction to grammatical analysis; morphology, syntax, semantics; synchronic analysis and description with illustrations from various languages. Analytical practice and seminar discussion.
name: LING 201
title: Linguistic Theory and Analysis II

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: LING
description: Study of language as a universal and uniquely human cognitive system: What universals do all languages share and how do languages differ? An investigation of sound systems, word-building, grammatical principles, language change, dialect variation, language acquisition, neurolinguistics. Recommended but not required for an honours, major, or minor in linquistics or speech sciences.
name: LING 100
title: Introduction to Language and Linguistics

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: LING
description: Practical skills for analyzing language using the Python programming language and relevant packages.
name: LING 242
title: Computational Tools for Linguistic Analysis

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: LING
description: Audition and speech perception, phonological organization, word learning, syntax, and pragmatics.
name: LING 222
title: Language Acquisition

subject: LING
description: Linguistic systems that learners of an additional language develop as they approximate towards the target language, and key questions about what this 'interlanguage' system reveals about how we learn languages.
name: LING 270
title: Introduction to Studies in Second Language Acquisition

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: LING
description: Introduction to syntactic analysis and theory, with emphasis on description and analysis of data from a wide variety of languages.
name: LING 300
title: Studies in Grammar

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: LING
description: Introduction to phonological analysis and theory, with a strong emphasis on description and analysis of data from a wide variety of languages.
name: LING 311
title: Studies in Phonology

subject: LING
description: Physiological and/or acoustic phonetics. Focus on experimental methods and analysis techniques. Topics may include: source-filter theory; spectral and temporal acoustic analysis, inter-articulator timing and motor coordination.
name: LING 314
title: Instrumental Phonetics

subject: LING
description: The analysis and theory of linguistic meaning with emphasis on formal techniques for semantic analysis and their application to empirical phenomena in language, including pragmatics.
name: LING 327
title: Introduction to Semantics

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: LING
description: The articulatory and acoustic properties of speech production and perception, including practice in phonetic transcription, instrumental recording, and the analysis of normal speech.
name: LING 313
title: Introduction to Linguistic Phonetics and Speech Science

subject: LING
description: Current issues in semantic theory.
name: LING 425
title: Advanced Semantics

subject: LING

title: Native Languages of the Americas

subject: MICB

title: Research Problem
