name: MICB 418
title: Industrial Microbiology and Biotechnology

subject: MIDW
description: Physiology of conception, pregnancy, lactation, fetal growth, labour, birth, transition to extra-uterine life, postpartum. A series of lectures and lab sessions.
name: MIDW 106
title: Reproductive Anatomy and Physiology

subject: MIDW
description: An interdisciplinary study of pregnancy and childbirth drawing on and integrating the disciplines of psychology, sociology, philosophy of science, anthropology, women's studies, and cultural studies.
name: MIDW 102
title: Birth and its Meaning

subject: MIDW
description: Online situation-based learning tutorials occurring simultaneously with MIDW 200 clinical placement.
name: MIDW 201
title: Clinical Skills for Midwifery Practice

subject: MIDW
description: Breastfeeding physiology, pathophysiology, and strategies for support of the dyad based on best-practice principles.  Discussion of major Canadian and international initiatives for the support and protection of breastfeeding.
name: MIDW 104
title: Lactation Consultation for Maternity Care Providers

subject: MIDW
description: Research designs used in midwifery research, types of studies reported in the midwifery and health care literature, research methodology and basic principles of epidemiology, biostatistics and social research.
name: MIDW 115
title: Research Methods for Midwives

subject: MIDW
description: Clinical care of women experiencing normal pregnancy, labour, birth, and puerperium.  Clinical education experiences in preventative and therapeutic midwifery care with emphasis on prenatal and postnatal midwifery care.  Clinical practice education opportunities within the province.  Pass/Fail.
name: MIDW 200
title: Introduction to Midwifery Clinical Care

subject: MIDW
description: Principles of evidence-informed midwifery, what counts as evidence? Making sense of the evidence, applying the evidence in practice.
name: MIDW 210
title: Evidence-Informed Midwifery

subject: MIDW
description: Scope of practice of a midwife, regulatory framework, skills for basic midwifery practice. A series of lectures and clinical lab sessions.
name: MIDW 108
title: Foundations for Midwifery Practice

subject: MIDW
description: Social and economic determinants of maternal and fetal health worldwide, innovative public health strategies to reducing maternal and infant mortality and morbidity, and the impact of conflict on the health of mothers and babies.  Ethical considerations related to global clinical placements and medical tourism.  Theoretical course in preparation for global clinical placement.  Pass/Fail.
name: MIDW 360
title: Global Maternal Infant Health

subject: MIDW
description: Principles of physical assessment, physical and psychological assessment of the mother and neonate. A series of lectures and clinical lab sessions.
name: MIDW 107
title: Physical Assessment

subject: MIDW
description: Clinical course providing opportunity to study midwifery in contexts beyond those usually offered on the program. Students select context and provide rationale for how the context will enhance their learning.
name: MIDW 380
title: Midwifery in Special Contexts

subject: MIDW
description: Professional issues in midwifery including responsibilities and conduct, self-care, peer review, interprofessional relations and communication, legal and business concepts, and continuous quality assurance and improvement in practice.  A series of lectures and workshops delivered in an intensive format over two weeks.
name: MIDW 325
title: Professional Issues in Midwifery

subject: MIDW
description: Clinical education for midwifery care of pregnancy, birth, and the puerperium with an empahsis on abnormal situations in pregnancy, labour and birth, and in newborns.  Clinical practicum around the province.  Pass/Fail.
name: MIDW 420
title: Advanced Midwifery Clinical Care

subject: MIDW
description: Theoretical principles of care for pregnancy, birth, and the puerperium with an emphasis on the recognition and management of variations of normal and findings outside of normal.  Consists of a one-week intensive time in Vancouver, during which emergency skills certification is acquired, and weekly web-based tutorials.
name: MIDW 305
title: Midwifery Theory for Variations in Primary Care

subject: MIDW
description: An original piece of scholarship that builds on knowledge and skills acquired from coursework and in consultation with faculty mentors. This self-directed course can be taken in year 1, 2, or 3 of the Program.
name: MIDW 310
title: Senior Research Project

subject: MIDW
description: Clinical course focusing on consolidation of skills and knowledge of all aspects of midwifery care.
name: MIDW 322
title: Midwifery Primary Care

subject: MIDW
description: Theory, knowledge, strategies, and skills of person-centered counselling including family systems, trauma theory, theory, grief counselling, motivational interviewing skills, self-awareness and mindfulness, interprofessional communication, and cultural competency in continuity of care.
name: MIDW 101
title: Counselling for Maternity Care Providers

subject: MIDW
description: Theoretical principles for midwifery care of pregnancy, labour, birth, newborns, and the puerperium.  Emphasis on assessment and management skills for abnormal situations.  Includes a five-day intensive session in Vancouver, a series of online tutorials, and lab practice.
name: MIDW 405
title: Advanced Topics in Midwifery Theory and Practice

subject: MIDW
description: Ethics using ethical theory in health care and midwifery.
name: MIDW 215
title: Ethics in Maternity Care

subject: MIDW
description: Introduction to diagnostics related to cellular and humoral immune responses in pregnant women and newborns, the properties of viruses, epidemiology, the principles of bacterial pathogenesis, and related physiologic responses.
name: MIDW 103
title: Applied Health Services for Maternity Providers

subject: MIDW
description: Opportunities to explore health professions that partner with midwives to care for the childbearing family within the province.  Pass/Fail.
name: MIDW 350A
title: Interprofessional Placement - INTER PROF PLCMT

subject: MIDW
description: An overview of basic concepts in pharmacology, pharmacy, and therapeutics relevant to the practice of midwifery in Canada.
name: MIDW 125
title: Pharmacology for Maternity Care Providers

subject: MIDW
description: Students assume a primary care role in clinical placements in midwifery practices across the provinces.  Demonstration of independent decision making and application of the full range of their academic knowledge to professional practice.  A practicum under the supervision of a registered midwife.  Pass/Fail.
name: MIDW 440
title: Clinical Clerkship

subject: MIDW
description: Clinical education experiences with the preventative and therapeutic midwifery care of pregnancy, birth, and the puerperium.  Emphasis on the recognition and management of variations of normal and findings outside normal.  A 12-week practicum in locations around the province.  Pass/Fail.
name: MIDW 320
title: Variations in Midwifery Clinical Care

title: Comprehensive Midwifery Theory and Practice

subject: MIDW
description: Care of normal pregnancy, labour, birth, and puerperium with an empahsis on the intrapartum period and assessment and management skills.  Inludes a four-week intensive session in Vancouver, a series of online tutorials, and simulation and skills lab practice.

title: Midwifery Theory for Primary Care

comments:
PLACEMENT PROCEDURE: ALL students who wish to take Music 100 must pass the Music 100 Placement Test given on the first Wednesday morning of classes in September. 
You must sign up to take the test. 
If you are a B.Mus. student, sign up by registering for Music 100, and see this page for test information and samples: https://music.ubc.ca/new-undergrad-students/
If you are not a B.Mus. student, email j.roeder@ubc.ca to sign up for the test, and see this page for test information and samples:
https://music.ubc.ca/bachelor-of-arts-in-music/

comments:

in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: ORPA

During each weekly two hour session, patients with difficult management problems are presented for clinical evaluation and discussion of medical and orthopaedic treatment.

title: Rheumatology Conference

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD

name: ORPA 721
title: Orthopaedic Seminars

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: ORPA

title: Orthopaedic Surgery

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: ORPA
description: Orthopaedic traumatology is reviewed, with emphasis being placed on applied basic science, surgical anatomy, diagnosis and definitive management. These sessions are supervised by a faculty member and are held weekly, each session lasting one hour.
name: ORPA 724
title: Trauma Rounds

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: ORPA

name: ORPA 725
title: Bone Tumour Registry

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: ORPA
description: A series of 60 seminars in orthopaedics and traumatic surgery given over a two-year period: thirty sessions in each of the two years. One evening per week throughout the Winter Session. For post-graduate students proceeding to Certification and Fellowship of the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada.
name: ORPA 904
title: Seminar in Orthopaedics

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these programs: MD
-OR-
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: ORPA
description: The second year of the above program which will be given in alternate years.
name: ORPA 509
title: Advanced Orthopaedics II

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: ORPA
description: Evaluation of new patients and diagnosis and treatment of appropriate diseases. Basic signs and clinical features are both stressed in the total management of the patient. Two hours per week in the Outpatient Department under supervision of an orthopaedics faculty member.
name: ORPA 715
title: Orthopaedic Clinic

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: ORPA

name: ORPA 719
title: Orthopaedic Surgical Anatomy

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: ORPA
description: Evaluation of orthopaedic diseases and injuries in patients at bedside. A review of clinical features is correlated with relevant physiology and pathology.
name: ORPA 716
title: Orthopaedic Bedside Clinic

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: ORPA
description: Case presentation in paediatric orthopaedics, stressing history, physical findings and total management of the patient, including a review of paediatric fractures with x-rays.
name: ORPA 722
title: Paediatric Orthopaedics

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: OSOT
description: Professional identity, professionalism, and cultural humility are further explored. Knowledge is applied to develop self-directed, culturally safe, lifelong learners. Conscious use of theory, evidence and critical thinking will be utilized to maintain, evaluate and improve occupational therapy practice.
name: OSOT 549
title: Professional Development of the Occupational Therapist II

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: OSOT
description: Current legislative, socio-political, economic, cultural, and service delivery issues influencing occupational therapy practice are addressed. The structural, systemic, and contextual influences upon clients' health and occupations are also examined.
name: OSOT 551
title: Societal and Environmental Influences on Occupation and Occupational Therapy Practice

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: OSOT
description: A 3-term course, builds upon year 1 to further develop professional reasoning skills, synthesize theory and practice approaches in occupational therapy, and provide opportunities to acquire assessment and intervention skills according to the competencies required to enter occupational therapy practice.
name: OSOT 545
title: Occupation in Practice III: Occupational Therapy Assessment and Intervention

subject: OSOT
description: Preparation for practice concepts to facilitate integration of knowledge and skills introduced in term 1 of the MOT program. Demonstration of emerging Occupational Therapy competencies for a total of 5 weeks of supervised fieldwork experience in affiliated agencies is required.
name: OSOT 528
title: Occupational Therapy Practice: Fieldwork I

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: OSOT
description: Building on OSOT 511 and OSOT 515, complex skills and approaches to enable client occupational engagement are applied through workshops and labs. Biomechanical, psychosocial, neuro-rehabilitative and developmental frames of reference will inform professional reasoning as students work through the occupational therapy practice process.
name: OSOT 525
title: Occupation in Practice II: Advancing Theory, Assessment and Intervention

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: OSOT
description: Labs, simulations and tutorials provide opportunities to practice evidenced based foundational skills, techniques and approaches in preparation for occupational therapy practice in the local and regional context.
name: OSOT 515
title: Occupation in Practice I: Foundation of Occupational Therapy Assessment and Intervention

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: OSOT
description: Evidence of integration and synthesis of complex knowledge and skills provided throughout the MOT program to demonstrate Occupational Therapy advanced competencies for a total of 14 weeks of supervised fieldwork experience in affiliated health agencies.
name: OSOT 558
title: Occupational Therapy Practice: Fieldwork III

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: OSOT
description: To address inequities and meet the occupational needs of diverse communities, students will learn, critique and apply program development principles. Program development principles include needs assessment, program design, budgeting and resource planning, marketing, program evaluation, and proposal writing and presentation.
name: OSOT 553
title: Innovations in Occupation: Developing and Evaluating Occupational Therapy Programs

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: OSOT
description: Fundamentals of occupational therapy, including values and beliefs, conceptual models, client-centred principles, and practice process frameworks are introduced. Professional reasoning is demonstrated through resolution of case-based client occupational issues. Critical appraisal of theory fosters nuanced understandings of occupation and health.
name: OSOT 511
title: Fundamentals of Occupational Therapy: Theory, Conceptual Models and the Practice Process

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: OSOT
description: Concepts and models of occupation, health, and illness are introduced and appraised. Narratives from persons with lived experience and interactive assignments are used for acquiring biopsychosocial information on health conditions that impact occupational performance across lifespan and diverse life experiences.
name: OSOT 513
title: Health, Illness and Occupation

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: OSOT
description: Concepts of professionalism, reflexivity, cultural humility and collaboration are introduced to develop the skills of a self-directed, culturally safe, lifelong learner, who consciously uses theory, evidence and critical thinking skills to maintain, evaluate and improve their practice of occupational therapy.
name: OSOT 519
title: Professional Development of the Occupational Therapist I

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: OSOT
description: Enhances knowledge of research (or program evaluation) process and provides hands-on experience to create, inform, and disseminate evidence relevant to occupational science or occupational therapy.
name: OSOT 547
title: Developing Evidence for Occupational Therapy Practice

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
subject: OSOT
description: Assumptions and principles of qualitative and quantitative research designs; elements of basic research designs for investigating and evaluating occupational performance and diverse issues relevant to occupational science and occupational therapy are introduced, emphasizing critical appraisal of occupational therapy research literature.
name: OSOT 527
title: Becoming an Evidence-Informed Occupational Therapy Practitioner

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these programs: BMLS
subject: PATH
description: Introductory lectures and laboratory sessions in clinical chemistry, haematology and blood banking, hospital microbiology, preparation and examination of tissue sections. For Medical Laboratory Science students without previous experience in hospital laboratories.
name: PATH 300
title: Background to Medical Laboratory Science

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: PATH
description: An integrated approach to specific areas of the theoretical and practical aspects of those physical and biological sciences relevant to medical laboratory science. Emphasis will be placed upon the application of basic science to those clinical disciplines practised by the medical laboratory scientist, e.g., histochemistry, clinical chemistry, microbiology, haematology, etc.
name: PATH 301
title: Basic and Physical Biochemistry for Medical Laboratory Scientists

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: PATH
description: Fundamentals of human genetics and molecular biology as they relate to studying and detecting disease in a population; tissue culture techniques to assess cell viabilities; cytomorphology principles in disease detection.
name: PATH 303
title: Cytogenetics, Molecular Genetics, Tissue Culture and Cytology

subject: PATH
description: A lecture and laboratory course in the theoretical and practical application of modern biological microscopes - compound, dissecting, comparison, dark ground, fluorescent, phase contrast, interference and electron microscopes.
name: PATH 305
title: Modern Microscopy

subject: PATH
description: An advanced lecture and laboratory course in the microscopic structure of the human body necessary for a complete understanding of histochemistry and histopathology.
name: PATH 304
title: Normal Human Histology

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these programs: BMLS
subject: PATH
description: Control processes for workplace hazards of radiological, chemical, and biological origin.
name: PATH 306
title: Laboratory Safety for Medical Laboratory Scientists

subject: PATH
description: Descriptions of each group of human microbial pathogens according to biological attributes, clinical features, pathogenesis and pathology, epidemiology, immunological reactions, laboratory diagnosis, principles of antimicrobial therapy, preventative measures. For students in the Faculty of Medicine B.M.L.Sc.
name: PATH 327
title: Bacteriology, Mycology, Virology and Parasitology

subject: PATH
description: A lecture-demonstration course designed to acquaint students in the allied health professions with a basic understanding of the causes, natural history, and pathophysiology of common disease processes.
name: PATH 375
title: Introduction to Human Pathology

subject: PATH
description: Students acquire content relating to the virulence factors of the bacteria and the pathophysiology of the host while working through case scenarios on their own and in online groups. Students taking this course must be willing to engage in both self-directed and small-group learning.
name: PATH 417A
title: Human Bacterial Infections - HMN BACT INFCTNS

subject: PATH
description: Oral and written presentation and critical appraisal of scientific papers.
name: PATH 405
title: Seminars in Current Topics

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in one of these faculties: GRAD
Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: PATH
name: PATH 548P
title: Directed Studies - GENOME ANALYSIS

subject: PATH
description: Personnel management, staff management relationships, stock control, record keeping, etc. Medicolegal aspects of medical laboratory science. Theory and practice of quality control. Use of computers in the medical laboratory.
name: PATH 408
title: Laboratory Administration

subject: PATH
description: This course provides the basic principles to prevent the spread of microorganisms pathogenic to humans. It may be taken towards a Certificate in Infection Control.
name: PATH 427
title: Basic Principles of Infection Prevention and Control

subject: PATH
description: The identification, clinical significance, and transmission of pathogenic organisms are presented. This course is available by correspondence or webCT. It may be taken towards fulfillment of the Certificate in Infection Control.
name: PATH 467
title: Basic Microbiology for Infection Control

subject: PATH
description: Immunological events causing tissue injury.
name: PATH 415
title: Immunopathology

name: PATH 548K
title: Directed Studies - HMST, THRM, HMPH

name: PATH 548O

subject: PHIL
description: The Pre-Socratics; Socrates; Sophists; Plato.  Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310.
name: PHIL 211
title: Greek Philosophy I: Socrates and Plato

subject: PHIL
description: Moral issues such as life and death decisions, paternalism, markets, animal welfare, technology, and global justice.
name: PHIL 235
title: Contemporary Moral Issues

subject: PHIL
description: Philosophical and theoretical issues that pertain to how mental phenomena fit into the material world. Examine questions such as whether a sophisticated enough computer should be deemed a conscious intelligent being. Focus on philosophical literature on consciousness, intelligence, animal minds, and the mind-body relation. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 250 or PHIL 150.
name: PHIL 250
title: Minds and Machines

subject: PHIL
description: Historical and logical analysis of various types of scientific hypotheses and the data that support or undermine them. This course is restricted to students with fewer than 90 credits.
name: PHIL 125
title: Introduction to Scientific Reasoning

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: PHIL
description: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as the nature and scope of human knowledge, the existence of God, and the relationship between mind and body. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 100 or PHIL 101.
name: PHIL 101
title: Introduction to Philosophy

subject: PHIL
description: Sentential and predicate logic. Translation from natural language; truth tables and interpretations; systems of natural deduction up to relational predicate logic with identity; alternative proof methods. Some sections may use computer-based materials and tests.
name: PHIL 220
title: Symbolic Logic

subject: PHIL
description: Aristotle; selections from Hellenistic and Late Antique Philosophy. Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310.
name: PHIL 212
title: Greek Philosophy II: Aristotle and After

subject: PHIL
description: Theories of obligation and value; moral reasoning; normative ethics, descriptive ethics and meta-ethics. Readings in classic and contemporary texts.
name: PHIL 230
title: Introduction to Ethics

subject: PHIL
description: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as morality, personal identity, free will and determinism, and the meaning of life. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 100 or PHIL 102.
name: PHIL 102
title: Introduction to Philosophy II

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: PHIL
description: Topics in epistemology such as skepticism, truth, justification, a priori and a posteriori knowledge. Readings from classic and contemporary texts.
name: PHIL 240
title: Introduction to Epistemology

comments:
This course is restricted to students
in year: <=3
subject: PHIL
description: Tools for dealing with both everyday and more technical arguments and concepts. Analysis and resolution of confusions, ambiguities, and fallacies. This course is restricted to students with fewer than 90 credits.
name: PHIL 120
title: Introduction to Critical Thinking

subject: PHIL
description: Philosophical approaches to historical problems of inequality and social harm, with readings drawn from historical and contemporary sources. Topics to be studied may include slavery, colonialism, labour, and the position of women in society.
name: PHIL 335
title: Power and Oppression

subject: PHIL
description: Issues common to all sciences. Philosophical questions including the character of scientific laws, theories and revolutions, the nature of scientific confirmation, causality, explanation and prediction, and the use of logic and probability. Difficulties in the interpretation of atomic physics and questions about relationships between biology and psychology. No philosophical background is assumed. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 369 or PHIL 460.
name: PHIL 369
title: Philosophy of Science

subject: PHIL
description: An examination of historical, conceptual and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science.
name: PHIL 360
title: Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science

subject: PHIL
description: The development of economic thought from Aristotle to Adam Smith, focusing primarily on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution, and economic growth.
name: PHIL 362
title: History and Philosophy of Economics from Aristotle to Adam Smith

subject: PHIL
description: One or more of conditional logic, deontic logic, epistemic logic, many-valued logic, systems of belief dynamics.
name: PHIL 323
title: Non-Classical Logics

subject: PHIL
description: Topics in metaphysics such as the nature of physical reality, personal identity, the mind/body problem, free will, causation and action theory. Readings from classic and contemporary texts.
name: PHIL 340
title: Introduction to Metaphysics

subject: PHIL
description: The development of economic thought from David Ricardo up to the present, including such figures as Mill, Jevons, and Keynes, focusing primarily on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution and growth.
name: PHIL 363
title: History and Philosophy of Economics from Ricardo to Keynes

subject: PHIL
description: Logic of the modal operators "It is necessary that" and "It is possible that." Possible-world semantics and a method of derivation for this logic.
name: PHIL 322
title: Modal Logic

subject: PHIL
description: Debates on issues of epistemology, language and ontology among the philosophical schools or systems of classical India Nagarjuna, Bhartrhari, Uma-svati, Sankara and others.
name: PHIL 388
title: Buddhist, Brahmanical and Jain Philosophers in Interaction.

subject: PHIL
description: Meaning, identity and alienation as explored in the works for example of Kierkegaard, Dostoyevsky, Tolstoy, Sartre, and Camus.
name: PHIL 385
title: Existentialism

subject: PHIL
description: Survey of 18th-century philosophy from Locke to Kant, including the writings of Berkeley, Rousseau, and Hume. The influence of science and religion on philosophy.
name: PHIL 315
title: Philosophy in the 18th Century

subject: PHIL
description: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century.
name: PHIL 364
title: Darwin, Evolution, and Modern History

subject: PHIL
description: A study of Plato's dialogues and his influence on subsequent philosophy.
name: PHIL 310
title: The Philosophy of Plato

subject: PHIL
description: Moral problems in contemporary business and professional practice, general moral theory, the law, and policy formation. Corporate social and environmental responsibility, employee rights, preferential hiring and affirmative action programs, conflicts of interest, advertising, "whistle blowing" and self-regulation. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 331 or PHIL 434.
name: PHIL 331
title: Business and Professional Ethics

subject: PHIL
description: Concepts of law, constitution and sovereignty; law and morality; natural law theories and legal positivism; obligation, responsibility, and punishment.
name: PHIL 338
title: Philosophy of Law

subject: PHIL
description: Topics include art and perception, art and reality, imagination, expression, censorship, and the role of art in human life.
name: PHIL 339
title: Philosophy of Art

subject: PHIL
description: Philosophical exploration of questions and theories arising from research into the mind, as conducted in psychology, linguistics, and computer science.
name: PHIL 351
title: Philosophical Perspectives on Cognitive Systems Research

subject: PHIL
description: Philosophical exploration of ethical issues in the non-medical sciences, including topics such as intellectual integrity, responsible conduct of research, protection of human subjects, ethics of animal experimentation, and the social responsibilities of scientists. Credit will be granted for only one of ISCI 433 or PHIL 337.
name: PHIL 337
title: Ethics for the Sciences

subject: PHIL
description: Moral problems arising in the health sciences, especially in medicine but also in biology, psychology, and social work. Topics include abortion, death and euthanasia, genetic engineering, behaviour modification, compulsory treatment, experimentation with human beings and animals, and the relationship between professionals and their patients, subjects or clients. No philosophical background is required. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 333 or PHIL 433.
name: PHIL 333
title: Bio-Medical Ethics

subject: PHIL
description: A critical and analytical examination of arguments for and arguments against the existence of God, and other related topics. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 347 or PHIL 349.
name: PHIL 347
title: Philosophy of Religion

subject: PHIL
description: Relationship between sex, gender, and philosophy. Topics may include ethics, epistemology, science, social relations, law, and personhood.
name: PHIL 334
title: Sex, Gender and Philosophy

subject: PHIL
description: A study of Aristotle's writings and his influence on subsequent philosophy.
name: PHIL 311
title: The Philosophy of Aristotle

subject: PHIL
description: Continuation of PHIL 220. A system of deduction for predicate logic is selected for further study. Completeness of this system and other metatheoretic results are proved. Other topics include computability, recursive function theory, incompleteness and decidability.
name: PHIL 320
title: Logic: Metatheory and Computability

description: Theories of political and legal obligation and authority, legal reasoning, society and the state. Readings in classic and contemporary texts.

title: Philosophy in the 17th Century

subject: PHIL
description: Survey of 19th and 20th century philosophy. May include Hegel, Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, Mill, Meinong, Brentano, the British Idealists, Russell, and Moore. Social and political currents in 19th century philosophical thought.
name: PHIL 316
title: Philosophy After 1800

subject: PHIL
description: Intensive study of a major philosopher or school such as Descartes, Hume, Empiricism, Rationalism, or the British utilitarians.
name: PHIL 414
title: Topics in the History of Modern Philosophy

subject: PHIL

subject: PHIL
description: Philosophical issues in works of literature or arising from theories of literary interpretation. Topics include issues relating to relativism, the nature of morality, free will, personal identity, the nature of the emotions.

subject: PHIL
description: Study of a major 19th-century philosopher such as Hegel, Mill or Nietzsche, or school, such as German Idealism.

subject: PHIL
description: Moral problems arising in the context of human relationships to nature and to non-human living things, considered in terms of both general moral theory and policy formation. Topics include moral standing, animal rights, obligations to future generations, pollution, hazardous materials, the depletion of natural resources and the treatment of non-human living things. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 332 or PHIL 435.
name: PHIL 332
title: Environmental Ethics

subject: PHIL
description: Intensive study of a major philosopher such as Wittgenstein, Russell, or Heidegger, or school, such as pragmatism or logical empiricism.

subject: PHIL

subject: PHIL

subject: PHIL

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)

title: Intermediate Experimental Physics II

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: PHYS
description: Special relativity: Lorentz transformation, dynamics and conservation laws. Quantum physics: the experimental evidence for quantization; a qualitative discussion of the concepts of quantum mechanics and their application to simple systems of atoms and nuclei.
name: PHYS 200
title: Relativity and Quanta

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: PHYS
description: Review of kinematics, Newton's laws, angular momentum and fixed axis rotation. Rigid body motion, central forces, non-inertial frames of reference. Introduction to Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics.
name: PHYS 216
title: Intermediate Mechanics

comments: Please consult the First Year Physics Guide for more information: http://www.phas.ubc.ca/undergrad-first-year-guide
Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: PHYS
description: Optics, electricity and magnetism, electric circuits, radioactivity, including biological applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
name: PHYS 118
title: Electricity, Light and Radiation

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: PHYS
description: Principles and applications of quantum mechanics, wave mechanics, the Schroedinger equation, expectation values, Hermitian operators, commuting observables,  one-dimensional systems, harmonic oscillators, angular momentum, three dimensional systems. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
name: PHYS 304
title: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics

subject: PHYS
description: Physical principles involved in biological systems at the microscopic and molecular scales. Diffusion, low Reynolds number dynamics, the physicist's view of biomolecular structure, models of molecular motors and membranes.
name: PHYS 305
title: Introduction to Biophysics

comments: PHYS 299:  FOR CO-OP STUDENTS ONLY  -  APPLY TO SCIENCE CO-OP OFFICE

description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

title: Co-operative Work Placement II

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: PHYS
description: Kinematics including curvilinear motion. Forces and Newton's laws of motion. Work-energy theorem, conservation of energy. Conservation of momentum, collisions. Torque, rotational dynamics, angular momentum. Oscillations and waves. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

title: Dynamics and Waves

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)

title: Electricity and Magnetism

title: Advanced Mechanics

subject: PHYS
description: Electricity and magnetism, electrical circuits, induction, electromagnetic waves, Maxwell's equations and applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414

subject: STAT
description: Classical, nonparametric, and robust inferences about means, variances, and analysis of variance, using computers. Emphasis on problem formulation, assumptions, and interpretation. See the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
name: STAT 200
title: Elementary Statistics for Applications

comments:
This course is restricted to students
not in any of these programs: BSC
Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: STAT
description: Organizing, displaying and summarizing data. Inference estimation and testing for elementary probability models. Not for credit towards a B.Sc. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.)
name: STAT 203
title: Statistical Methods

subject: STAT
description: Probability, discrete and continuous random variables, joint probability distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, analysis of variance, goodness of fit. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar).
name: STAT 251
title: Elementary Statistics

subject: STAT
description: Basic notions of probability, random variables, expectation and conditional expectation, limit theorems. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.)
name: STAT 302
title: Introduction to Probability

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: STAT
description: Further topics in statistical inference, including parametric and non-parametric methods, goodness-of-fit methods, analysis of variance and covariance, regression analysis, categorical data analysis, experimental designs, time series, model fitting, and statistical computing.
name: STAT 300
title: Intermediate Statistics for Applications

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: STAT
description: Review of probability theory. Sampling distribution theory, large sample theory and methods of estimation and hypothesis testing, including maximum likelihood estimation, likelihood ratio testing and confidence interval construction.
name: STAT 305
title: Introduction to Statistical Inference

comments: Choose one section from all 2 activity types. (e.g. Lecture and Laboratory)
subject: STAT
description: Modelling a response (output) variable as a function of several explanatory (input) variables:  multiple regression for a continuous response, logistic regression for a binary response, and log-linear models for count data.  Finding low-dimensional structure:  principal components analysis.  Cluster analysis.  (Consult the Credit Exclusion List within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar).
name: STAT 306
title: Finding Relationships in Data
